Hey there,
I need to fix my Android phone and I will use for several days an iPhone is there any problem that I can create a backup in my Android Phone and install it into an iPhone? Thanks

link_counts.title: Switching from Android to iPhone or vice versa - path to transfer backups?

posts.cooked:
You cannot.

There is no backup / restore function on the iOS app.
In other words. You will not have any old messages when you swith to the iPhone. And when you switch back, you will also loose all conversations you made in the meantime.

newuser:

Would it not sync the messages? Feels like it should (but with limits on duration, message count, file sizes, etc)

It wouldn’t sync the messages. But, the primary device, as soon as it is connected to the internet, should receive a ton of push notifications, which will wake up Signal and it will start retrieving any kind of messages that are stored for that device on the service.

Don't demand registering the phone number again after restoring a backup

It’s the same device, with the same keys, and you haven’t re-registered. You would be able to retrieve messages from the ephemeral queue (with the caveat that the size of the ephemeral queue is limited by design).

"Message encrypted for non-existing session" while updating the Mac App

Each client, whether it is the primary mobile device or a linked device, can operate independently. The service uses an ephemeral queue to deliver end-to-end encrypted messages for offline clients like a mobile device in an elevator or a desktop device that hasn’t been launched in a while. However, that queue is capped and does not grow indefinitely, so if a device comes back online after an extended period of time some of the earlier messages may have fallen out of the queue and its attempts to send delivery confirmations or other messages may not be possible without resetting the session.

Thank you for the quotes and for making precise what I had meant by “sync messages”. It looks like re-registering will nuke the ephemeral queue. I guess the safest way is to buy some cheap Android phone and transfer backup to that and let it remain connected through wifi and then transfer again to the repaired device. OP could use this device or a linked device for regular usage.

Don't demand registering the phone number again after restoring a backup

The ephemeral queue is still cleared when you re-register with a backup.

Have they said anything else about what the queue cap is? WhatsApp, for example, makes it clear that the maximum is 30 days.
